data.title: Mishti Doi (sweet yoghurt)
data.meta_description: It is said, ‘A Bengali meal is incomplete without a sweet at its end’ and thus making Mishti Doi the most quintessential dessert of Bengali cuisine. In the vast and extensive range of Bengali desserts this simple, easy to make dessert makes its way into the everyday kitchen. As dahi/curd is also considered auspicious in Hindu…
data.text:
It is said, ‘A Bengali meal is incomplete without a sweet at its end’ and thus making Mishti Doi the most quintessential dessert of Bengali cuisine. In the vast and extensive range of Bengali desserts this simple, easy to make dessert makes its way into the everyday kitchen. As dahi/curd is also considered auspicious in Hindu religion, it is also prepared on festive occasions and celebrations like Durga Puja and Diwali.

Janmashtami or Gokulashtami is one of the important festivals of Hindus. Janmashtami commemorates the earthy appearance of lord Krishna. Dance-drama enactments of the life of Krishna such as Rasa Lila or Krishna Lila, devotional singing through the midnight when lord Krishna is believed to be born, fasting (upavasa), a night vigil (jagarana), and Mahotsav is part of Janmashtami celebrations. And offering him specially made food items. As an offering to the lord, people put together 56 food items called as Chhappan Bhog, which is later distributed among the people as prasad. Dahi is one of these Chhappan Bhog I made Mishti Doi on this auspicious day

Mishti Doi (sweet yogurt) is type of yogurt is common in the states of Odisha, West Bengal, Bihar in India, and in Bangladesh. It is made with milk and sugar/jaggery. It different from the plain yogurt because of the technique of preparation.

Mishti Doi is prepared by boiling milk until it is slightly thickened, sweetening it with sugar, jaggery, gura (brown sugar) or khejur gura (date molasses), curds and a pinch of elaichi (cardamom) is added for fragrance. Later allowing the milk to ferment overnight in earthen pots. Earthenware is always used as the container because the gradual evaporation of water through its porous walls thickens the yoghurt and produces the right temperature for the growth of the culture

Mishti Doi tastes great and is very simple to make!

Prep Time 5 mins

Cooking Time 40mins

Plus 8-10 hrs to set

Yields 6 servings

Ingredients

1 litre full cream/ whole milk

3-4 tbsp yogurt

250 gms sugar

Method
